channel.title: Comments on: Imperial College disavows the beloved Impact Factor. Boohoo.

item.title: By: Marco Aurelio Navarro
item.dc:creator: Marco Aurelio Navarro
item.description: And what about the list of conacyt's "recognized" editorial firms? That should also be included on a similar agreement in Mexico.
item.content:encoded: And what about the list of conacyt’s “recognized” editorial firms? That should also be included on a similar agreement in Mexico.

item.title: By: Pilar Orero
item.dc:creator: Pilar Orero
item.description: Congrats I hope UAB, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, follows soon and signs DORA soon
item.content:encoded: Congrats I hope UAB, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, follows soon and signs DORA soon

item.title: By: Rosa Nidia Buenfil
item.dc:creator: Rosa Nidia Buenfil
item.description: Good news from the Imperial College to everyone. I hope in Mexico Conacyt and other academic institutions -universities included- will at least consider this discussion instead of turning the blind eye to profound intellectual debates on academic assesment, and just follow the leaders of metrics and JIFs.
item.content:encoded: Good news from the Imperial College to everyone. I hope in Mexico Conacyt and other academic institutions -universities included- will at least consider this discussion instead of turning the blind eye to profound intellectual debates on academic assesment, and just follow the leaders of metrics and JIFs.

item.title: By: Imperial College disavows the beloved Impact Fa...
item.dc:creator: Imperial College disavows the beloved Impact Fa...
item.description: […] Yippee! Imperial College London have signed DORA, the San Francisco Declaration on Research Assessment! This basically means that the impact factor will no longer be used for research assessment. This follows the widespread documentation of its inherent flaws its but perplexing and continued mis-use. This is HUGE. Impact factors will no longer be promoted, either directly or indirectly, in staff assessments. This means that people have to actually use methods that make sense when it comes to defining the structure of academia. Fancy that!  […]
item.content:encoded: […] Yippee! Imperial College London have signed DORA, the San Francisco Declaration on Research Assessment! This basically means that the impact factor will no longer be used for research assessment. This follows the widespread documentation of its inherent flaws its but perplexing and continued mis-use. This is HUGE. Impact factors will no longer be promoted, either directly or indirectly, in staff assessments. This means that people have to actually use methods that make sense when it comes to defining the structure of academia. Fancy that!  […]
